urn:contentItem:6100-GN11-JD34-V0NK-00000-00Are we finally wising up to big tech?2020-09-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:21ZLexisNexisCOMPANIES AND MARKETSPg. 29Are we finally wising up to big tech?Max Mason

The unintended consequences of technology giants such as Facebook and Google have been bubbling away for a decade.

In the midst of a global pandemic, with fault lines emerging in democracy and journalism under pressure as never before, are people finally listening to the warnings about big tech that have been shouted from the rooftops for years?

Netflix's "docudrama" The Social Dilemma explores these unintended consequences through the eyes of former employees from Google, Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest - even the creator of Facebook's "like" button - and melodramatic scenes of a fictional American family using and abusing tech in 2020.

The teenage son falls for conspiracy theories and is arrested, and a "tween" daughter's self-worth spirals downwards as she becomes addicted to likes and filtered photos.

The tech industry has never been great at taking criticism and its solution to any problem seems to be more new and innovative products, rather than addressing a question of societal good and morality. That is not to say the media is faultless - far from it - but it has a self-deprecating dimension that tech often lacks.

The forceful - some would argue over-the-top - threats with which Google and Facebook have responded to a proposed Australian code of conduct aiming to force them to pay for the journalism they use on their platforms perfectly illustrate big tech's inability to take criticism.

The world is watching the attempt by Australian Competition and Consumer Commission chairman Rod Sims to regulate Google and Facebook in the hope that the code can work. This isn't a random, kooky regulator with a hare-brained idea.

Google and Facebook blame digital classifieds businesses such as SEEK and Carsales for traditional media's struggles - and they have played a part. But the tech giants shirk any responsibility. The companies have unprecedented global scale and reach, and have on multiple occasions been found abusing this near monopoly power. Their scale has given them a stranglehold over digital advertising. They enjoy the benefits of posting journalism on their platforms and say they deliver their value in clicks, so they shouldn't have to pay the media companies.

Google has aggressively fought the code. It says it is prepared to pay for content, but there is a huge discrepancy between what it offers and what media companies hope mandatory payment under the code of conduct will deliver.

Facebook is so opposed to paying for journalism that it has threatened to ban it from its platform in Australia.

The Social Dilemma describes at length how the platforms' algorithms manipulate their users - hitting them at their most vulnerable - to steal more and more of their time so they can be shown even more ads to garner more profits for the tech giants.

This isn't all new. Social media has played a big part in the steady rise in teen anxiety and self-harm. Fake news spreads faster than real news, and we know tech algorithms are designed to feed people content they're more likely to engage with so as to draw them farther down the rabbit hole.

Conspiracy groups such as Wake Up Australia - which doesn't believe COVID-19 is a real threat - continue to be recommended to Facebook users, illustrating the tech giant's apathy about the problem of engagement being promoted regardless of the truth.

The film puts all this forcefully. It's easy for these mostly male "tech bros" who have made their fortunes and moved on to say: "Oops, we didn't realise what we were doing. Sorry, it needs to change."

Thanks to Steve Jobs, the smartphone's glow has become ever-present in the daily lives of billions of people. Yet Jobs reportedly didn't let his kids use iPads.

"A computer to me is the most remarkable tool we've come up with ... it's the equivalent of a bicycle for our minds," Jobs said in 1981 about a Scientific American experiment that showed how well humans had improved their locomotive efficiency by inventing the bicycle.

Former Google design ethicist Tristan Harris, co-founder of the Centre for Humane Technology and a contributor to The Social Dilemma, throws Jobs' 1981 quote back at the audience.

"No one got upset when bicycles showed up, right?" he says. "When everyone started to go around on bicycles, none said: 'Oh my god we've just ruined society.' Like 'bicycles are affecting people, they're pulling people away from their kids, they're ruining the fabric of democracy, people can't tell what's true'. Like, we never said any of that stuff about a bicycle.

"If something is a tool, it genuinely is just sitting there, waiting patiently. If something is not a tool, it's demanding things from you, it's seducing you, it's manipulating you ... Social media isn't a tool that's just waiting to be used. It has its own goals, and it has its own means of pursuing them by using your psychology against you."

The problem with the film is that it's short on solutions, other than "delete all apps" and "turn off notifications". The director reportedly did not give the tech companies a right of reply, though we've heard it all before - "we're working hard, we're developing new AI products to help" - and fault is never really admitted, let alone acted on.

The Social Dilemma would have us believe the evils of Google, Facebook et al are the logical conclusion of capitalism - a "profit at all costs" model. It fails to understand capitalism and the many examples of companies recognising something has to change, and acting before government does.

Shareholders have forced - and some companies have independently implemented - a range of important changes with climate policy. A long list of banks, including Australia's big four, financial institutions and insurance companies have shunned the controversial Adani Carmichael coal mine and associated operations.

The problem at Facebook is control is centralised around founder and chief executive Mark Zuckerberg and his iron grip on the social media giant's voting stock.

Capitalism is about the market working through the most efficient means of operating, which may include decisions that hurt short-term profits but benefit long-term profits and social standing. Facebook shareholders simply can't force any change because all the power resides with one man.

The unintended consequences of Google and Facebook not seeing the writing on the wall - that they do get value from news, and it is actually worth paying for - are weaker media outlets, job losses, and proliferation of fake news on their platforms, driving conspiracy theories, social divide and profits for the tech giants.

That's why the Australian government and ACCC stepped in with a code to force Facebook and Google to pay for the value journalism on their platforms.

Speculation is Treasury and the ACCC will look to work through changes to the draft code, proposed in late July, to be put to the government in the first week of October, with the intention of introducing the legislation into Parliament between October 19 and 29, although this is fluid.

The code is one small step that Facebook and Google need to take, and will probably be followed around the world if it works. The harder steps will be weaning themselves off their own morphine drip of quarterly profit growth to sustain their businesses in the long-term, instead of waiting until they implode.

urn:contentItem:60YY-DRX1-DY19-C52Y-00000-00Are we finally wising up to Big Tech?2020-09-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:21ZLexisNexisAre we finally wising up to Big Tech?Max Mason

The tech industry has never been great at taking criticism. Its response to any problem is to create a slew of new products rather than take a good hard look at itself.

The unintended consequences of technology giants such as Facebook and Google have been bubbling away for a decade.

Now in the midst of a global pandemic, with fault lines emerging in democracy and journalism under pressure as never before, are people finally listening to the warnings about Big Tech that have been shouted from the rooftops for years?

Netflix's "docudrama" The Social Dilemma explores these unintended consequences through the eyes of former employees from Google, Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest - even the creator of Facebook's "like" button - and melodramatic scenes of a fictional American family using and abusing tech in 2020.

Ultimately the teenage son falls for conspiracy theories and is arrested, and a "tween" daughter's self-worth spirals downwards as she becomes addicted to likes and filtered photos.

The tech industry has never been great at taking criticism and its solution to any problems seems to be more new and innovative products, rather than addressing an actual question of societal good and morality. That is not to say the media are faultless - far from it, but they have a self-deprecating dimension tech often lacks.

The forceful - some would argue over-the-top - threats with which Google and Facebook have responded to a proposed Australian code of conduct aiming to force them to pay for the journalism they use on their platforms perfectly illustrate Big Tech's inability to take criticism.

Shirking responsibility

The world is watching the attempt by Australian Competition and Consumer Commission chairman Rod Sims to regulate Google and Facebook in the hope that the code can work. This isn't a random, kooky regulator with a hare-brained idea. It's a global issue many governments and regulators want to resolve.

Spain and France have failed in their attempts to make the platforms pay for journalism. Google and Facebook blame digital classifieds businesses such as SEEK and Carsales for traditional media's struggles - and they have played a part. But the tech giants shirk any responsibility and deny they've done any harm.

The two companies have unprecedented global scale and reach, and have on multiple occasions been found abusing this near monopoly power. Their scale has given them a stranglehold over digital advertising to a point that only makes financial sense because of their size. They enjoy the benefits of posting journalism on their platforms and say they deliver their value in clicks, so they shouldn't have to pay the media companies.

Google and Facebook have inserted themselves as intermediaries between publishers and consumers and continue to argue the value of journalism on their platforms is negligible. Google has aggressively fought the code. It says it is prepared to pay for content, but there is a huge discrepancy between what it offers and what media companies hope mandatory payment under the code of conduct will deliver.

So opposed is Facebook to paying for journalism that it has threatened to ban it from its platform in Australia altogether. This would undoubtedly harm Facebook and Australia, making the country an easier target for foreign manipulation.

"Without a common set of facts, it's hard to move people towards a common end," Michael Jensen, associate professor at the Institute for Governance and Policy Analysis at the University of Canberra, told a Senate committee on foreign interference through social media last Friday.

The Social Dilemma describes at length how the platform's algorithms manipulate their users - hitting them at their most vulnerable - to steal more and more of their time so they can be shown even more ads to garner more profits for the tech giants.

Time to wake up?

This isn't all new. Social media has played a big part in the steady rise in teen anxiety and self-harm. Fake news spreads faster than real news, and we know tech algorithms are designed to feed people content they're more likely to engage with so as to draw them farther down the rabbit hole.

Conspiracy groups like Wake Up Australia - which doesn't believe COVID-19 is a real threat - continue to be recommended to Facebook users, perfectly illustrating the tech giant's apathy about the problem of engagement being promoted regardless of the truth.

The film puts all this forcefully, even manipulatively. It's very easy for these mostly male "tech bros" who've made their fortunes and moved on to say, "oops, we didn't realise what we were doing. Sorry, it needs to change".

We all know we should spend less time on our phones. Thanks to Steve Jobs the smartphone's glow has become ever-present in the daily lives of billions of people across the world. Yet Jobs reportedly didn't let his kids use iPads.

"A computer to me is the most remarkable tool we've come up with ... it's the equivalent of a bicycle for our minds," Jobs said in 1981 about a Scientific American experiment that showed how well humans had improved their locomotive efficiency relative to other species by inventing the bicycle.

Former Google design ethicist Tristan Harris, co-founder of the Centre for Humane Technology and an omnipresent contributor to The Social Dilemma, throws Jobs' 1981 quote back at the audience.

"No one got upset when bicycles showed up, right?" he says. "When everyone started to go around on bicycles, none said 'oh my god we've just ruined society'. Like 'bicycles are affecting people, they're pulling people away from their kids, they're ruining the fabric of democracy, people can't tell what's true'. Like, we never said any of that stuff about a bicycle.

"If something is a tool, it genuinely is just sitting there, waiting patiently. If something is not a tool, it's demanding things from you, it's seducing you, it's manipulating you, it wants things from you.

"We've moved away from having a tools-based technology environment to an addiction and a manipulation-based technology environment. That's what's changed.

"Social media isn't a tool that's just waiting to be used. It has its own goals, and it has its own means of pursuing them by using your psychology against you."

The problem with the film is that it's short on solutions, other than "delete all apps" and "turn off notifications". The director reportedly did not give the tech companies a right of reply, though we've heard it all before - "we're working hard, we're developing new AI products to help" - and fault is never really admitted, let alone acted on.

The Social Dilemma would have us believe the evils of Google, Facebook et al are the logical conclusion of capitalism - a "profit at all costs" model. It fails to understand capitalism and the many examples of companies recognising something has to change and acting before government does.

Zuckerberg's iron grip

Shareholders have forced - and some companies have independently implemented - a range of important changes with climate change policy. A long list of banks, including Australia's big four, financial institutions and insurance companies have shunned the controversial Adani Carmichael coal mine and associated operations.

The problem at Facebook is control is centralised around founder and chief executive Mark Zuckerberg and his iron grip on the social media giant's voting stock.

Capitalism is about the market working through the most efficient means of operating, which may include decisions that hurt short-term profits but benefit long-term profits and social standing. Facebook shareholders simply can't force any change because all the power resides with one man.

"Facebook operates essentially as a dictatorship ... Our board is locked into an outdated governance structure that reduces board accountability to shareholders," says one shareholder proposal from 2019.

Tech giants like Facebook and Google refuse to acknowledge the unintended consequences of their unprecedented growth and stranglehold over the advertising and media industries, and the human population in general.

The unintended consequences of Google and Facebook not seeing the writing on the wall - that they do get value from news, and it is actually worth paying for - are weaker media outlets, job losses, and proliferation of fake news on their platforms, driving conspiracy theories, social divide and profits for the tech giants.

That's why the Australian government and ACCC stepped in with a code to force Facebook and Google to pay for the value journalism on their platforms.

Speculation is Treasury and the ACCC will look to work through changes to the draft code, proposed in late July, to be put to government in the first week of October, with the intention of introducing the legislation into Parliament in the sitting period between October 19 and 29, although this is fluid.

The code is one small step that Facebook and Google need to take, and will likely be followed around the world if it works. The harder steps will be weaning themselves off their own morphine drip of quarterly profit growth to sustain their businesses in the long-term, instead of waiting until they implode.

urn:contentItem:5W72-NVT1-JBCN-40HD-00000-00Are we more or less open for people to speak freely?2019-05-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:21ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A5Are we more or less open for people to speak freely?KYLE WINGFIELD

In terms of law and court precedents, speech has arguably never been freer. When it comes to voicing a contrary opinion on the most sensitive political and cultural topics, however, many of our tongues are tied and our fingers shy away from the keyboard. Better not to say anything, we reason, than to deal with the blow back.

The answer to this speech-chilling political correctness is not a new law but personal courage, free speech attorney-turned-writer David French of the National Review Institute argued this past week in a speech in Atlanta.

“We’ve reached a position that is different from the classic defense of free speech in this country,” French said. Rather than admitting none of us knows everything, and thus some humility is in order, too many Americans won’t accept they may need to change their minds from time to time. Or that they would benefit from explaining their own opinion, and not shouting down their opponents.

Much of the problem stems from what’s been called “the big sort” – the physical movement of people toward places where their neighbors will be more like-minded. “Americans are less likely to live near and work with people who disagree with them than at any time since we’ve been measuring that,” French said.

But because people tend to become more extreme in their views when they only talk with those who agree with them, we’ve lost not only our willingness to engage with others but the belief we even need to do so.

How bad has it gotten? “People are more likely to prefer their son or daughter marry a person of a different faith than a different political party,” French said, quipping that for many on the right, “eternal damnation is preferable to a Democrat.”

Although these attitudes concern politics, count French as someone who does not believe there’s a political solution. Rather, a cultural solution is needed. And that’s where the personal courage comes in.

“We cannot allow ourselves to be intimidated into silence,” he said, because that silence becomes self-reinforcing and makes it harder to speak up the next time.

But the answer is not to fight fire with fire.

“The opposite of political correctness is not acting like a jerk,” French said. “It’s speaking the truth with grace and humility and fearlessness. There is such a thing as being fearlessly reasonable.”

Along with that is a legal corollary to the Golden Rule: “Defend the rights of others that you would like to exercise yourself.”

And an answer to the “snowflake” mentality on many college campuses: “Do your best to be unoffendable. Be a walking safe space for speech.”

French takes as much abuse on social media (specifically Twitter) as anyone I observe. But while he acknowledges those platforms “put human nature on blast,” and not in a good way, he said they’re not the root cause of these problems.

“It’s as old as the high school cafeteria,” he said. “It’s peer pressure.”

As in that context, the answer to political correctness is to stand up to the peer pressure rather than conform to it to stay with the “in” crowd.

Contrary to some pleas, however, he isn’t for treating big tech companies like Facebook and Google as public utilities, or using antitrust power to break them up. “If you have one ‘woke’ Google and you break into nine pieces, what are you going to have?” he posited. “Nine ‘woke’ Googles.”

The answer here is a mix of persuading the leaders of these behemoths not to stifle speech they don’t like, while encouraging entrepreneurs who want to compete with them. The worst approach would be to weaken that strong legal environment for free speech, and let government regulators decide what’s OK to say.

“If there’s one thing we know about politics,” he warned those who have the upper hand today, “it’s that no party maintains control for long.”

Kyle Wingfield is president and CEO of the Georgia Public Policy Foundation: www.georgiapolicy.org.

urn:contentItem:5X82-N6K1-JCMN-Y17R-00000-00Are you ready for America's data protection laws?2019-10-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:21ZLexisNexisAre you ready for America's data protection laws?Rakesh Soni, LoginRadius

Oct 12, 2019( VentureBeat: http://venturebeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) If your company is still grappling with Europe's data protection laws, then you'll want to step up your game. You'll soon have American data protection laws to deal with, too. California's Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA[1]) goes into effect January 1, 2020 — that's less than 3 months away. And additional American legislation is wending its way through various state houses in the United States, starting with New York (SHIELD Act[2]). Regardless of where your company is based, if you serve customers who live in California and New York, you must be compliant or face fines.

Since Europe rolled out GDPR, its landmark data privacy rules, 18 months ago, the online industry, despite having two years to prepare, has been hit with fine after fine for violations. During GDPR's first year, 90,000+[3] businesses voluntarily reported breaches as they struggled to attain compliance. This was topped with 145,000+[4] consumer complaints. Like most legislation, ignorance of the law is no excuse — and likewise, the offender's intent provides no safe harbor. Regulators pay no heed to whether a breach is accidental or the result of outright negligence. They do, however, levy greater fines for obvious, deliberate, or willful flaunting of the law. And EU regulators have famously made an example of some well-known companies. In January 2019, Google paid a €50 million fine[5] to French authorities for its lack of transparency in the collection and use of personal data for ad targeting. A few months earlier, a Portuguese hospital paid €400,000[6] for its poor patient record control practices. (For convenience, systems administrators created nearly 1,000 doctor-level access accounts. This allowed almost 1,000 user accounts to have unrestricted access to patient data when there were fewer than 300 actual doctors on staff.) A Danish taxi company was fined 1.2 million kroner[7] after it was discovered they had been hoarding more than 9 million customer records containing personally identifiable information, long after these were required for business purposes. This was in contravention of the GDPR's requirement to delete customer records when no longer required. And to the cheers of millions, Polish authorities pounced on a spamming operation[8] in their country that scraped email addresses from public web pages and aggregated these for sending unsolicited commercial email. 12,000 recipients from a 90,000-strong distribution list complained, resulting in a €220,000 fine. This list is far from exhaustive. An online GDPR enforcement tracker[9] is attempting to capture all of the abuses reported by European authorities under the new legislation, including a pending €204 million fine against British Airways[10] for a compromise involving 500,000 of its customers' payment information.Comparing the GDPR and CCPA: Some highlightsThere are some key differences[11] between the CCPA and GDPR. Broadly, the CCPA is less prescriptive about acceptable practices than GDPR, and even in the case of a reported infraction, the per-incident fine is insignificant unless a very large number of users report the problem. Minimum standard for being on the CCPA radar. Whereas the GDPR essentially has no minimum criteria for applicability, the CCPA will likely not govern your activity if your revenue is under $25 million and you're not in the business of transacting the personal data of more than 50,000 users — even if you have a breach. But if you do meet the minimum standard, your service gets compromised, and user data to is breached, CCPA bites down significantly harder than GDPR. Extent of fines. GDPR has caps in place to ensure that fines do not exceed a significant portion of an offender's revenue, but the only limit to the fines that could be levied against a CCPA offender is the number of users affected. The CCPA sets out a per user fine of $100 - $750 or actual damages (whichever is larger) for even an unintentional breach, so a smallish web service experiencing a breach of 1 million user accounts could easily be fined out of existence. User opt-out vs. opt-in. Under CCPA, users must opt out from information sharing with third-parties, whereas GDPR demands that users explicitly opt-in. In more general terms, the CCPA is more lenient (though it emphasises different attributes) around proactive disclosure and handling of minors. Speaking broadly, if your service is GDPR compliant, your practices will generally meet or exceed the expectations of CCPA.Less than half of companies appear readyThe extraterritoriality of GDPR means that if your business serves European customers, you're obligated to meet this legislation's stringent requirements, regardless of where your company is located. Similarly, if you're operating in or serving customers in any way in the United States, the New York and California-mandated protections will apply to you and your customers. According to an August 2019 IAPP and OneTrust[12] survey of mostly US businesses (of all sizes), while 74 percent of survey respondents believe their employer needs to comply with California's upcoming privacy rules, only around 2 percentsaid their companies are already fully prepared for it. Despite the growing havoc wreaked by GDPR, only 47 percent of survey respondents are expecting to be prepared for CCPA by the January 1 deadline. This is particularly true for organizations who are still not yet GDPR compliant. If your company isn't ready, then it's time to get serious. As GDPR has demonstrated, even a small, localized misjudgment can have huge consequences.https://venturebeat.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/cppa_readiness.jpg?resize=928%2C435...ip=all?strip=all Above: Survey question: Approximately when do you expect your organization to be in full compliance with the CCPA? (Results are show for 2 versions of the IAPP/OneTrust survey, one conducted in April and the most recent in August.) Even if you don't think either of these laws applies to your business today, it makes sense to apply their standards anyway. Non-applicability under the law does not exempt an organization from liability against civil suits in the event of a breach or compromised standards. Both these, and pending legislation around across the US and around the world, set a standard that judges may look at when considering cases (as yet untested under these laws) directly between companies and affected customers. And at the end of the day, protecting customers ultimately protects the trust in and reputation of your business and your brand — things that could have a higher value than potential fines now or down the road. Rakesh Soni is the Co-Founder and CEO of CIAM service provider LoginRadius[13].
